intro: Gilia rigidula subsp. acerosa, commonly known as the rigid gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its erect, branched stems and showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer. Its leaves are typically linear and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in dry, rocky habitats.
